comment: Proth's theorem (1878). If P is a _Proth number_, i.e. a number of the form k2^n+1 with k less than 2^n, and if there exists an integer x for which x^((P-1)/2) is -1 modulo P, then P is prime. Such a prime is called a _Proth prime_. Like Pocklington's theorem (see ~ pockthg ), Proth's theorem allows for a convenient method for verifying large primes. (Contributed by AV, 5-Jul-2020.)
